qas.question: What is recently considered the type of eclipse that occurred?
How long would a lunar eclipse be visible?
What person possibly made a mistake while copying text?

answers.text: a scribe wrongly amending a text

qas.question: Which historian says this opinion is indefensible?
What inconsistency would be found in this explanation?

answers.text: the lunar eclipse would not have been visible during daylight hours

qas.question: What university is David Henige employed by?
What event did David Henige believe might have happened instead of a solar eclipse?
For how many minutes did David Henige belive the lunar eclipse would be visible?
What city was Henige originally from?
What does Colin Humphreys dismiss the explanation as?

context: Colin Humphreys and W. G. Waddington of <b5_0>Oxford University<b5_0/> considered the possibility that a <a0_0><b6_0>lunar<b6_0/><a0_0/>, rather than solar, eclipse might have taken place. They concluded that such an eclipse would have been visible, for <a1_0><b7_0>thirty minutes<b7_0/><a1_0/>, from <b8_0>Jerusalem<b8_0/> and suggested the gospel reference to a solar eclipse was the result of <a2_0>a scribe wrongly amending a text<a2_0/>. Historian <a3_0>David Henige<a3_0/> dismisses this explanation as <b9_0>'indefensible'<b9_0/> and astronomer Bradley Schaefer points out that <a4_0>the lunar eclipse would not have been visible during daylight hours<a4_0/>.
